person_404.name: WilliamFeetham
person_404.description: Ironmonger and maker of apparatus of 296 Oxford Street. Described as having a workshop at the Royal Institution, annexed to the laboratory.

person_371.name: RichardKnight
person_371.description: Brother of George who were both scientific instrument makers based in Foster Lane, Cheapside, London.

person_403.name: Allen & Howard
person_403.description: The partnership of William Allen (1770-1843) and Luke Howard (1772-1864), from whom Davy bought chemicals and apparatus.

person_1102.name: RobertFidler
person_1102.description: Possibly: Robert Fidler an optical instrument maker with premises in Cavendish Square, London.

person_551.name: MichaelFaraday
person_551.description: From 1812 Davy used Faraday as his amanuensis and the following year secured his appointment as laboratory assistant at the Royal Institution. Despite a difficult relationship with Davy, Faraday later became the dominent figure at the Royal Institution and one of the leading scientific personalities of the middle third of the nineteenth century. FRSL.

person_055.name: ThomasDundas
person_055.description: Scottish-born politician and Whig MP, created (1794) first Baron Dundas of Aske. An early Proprietor of the Royal Institution and an Ordinary Member of the Board of Agriculture, he was a landowner, owning Loftus alum works. FRSL.

person_385.name: Samuel LathamMitchill
person_385.description: American chemist, botanist, natural historian and botanist, who studied medicine at the University of Edinburgh. He claimed nitrous oxide was poisonous (which Davy proved was wrong).

person_595.name: Charles FrancisGreville
person_595.description: A British antiquarian, collector and politician who sat in the House of Commons from 1774 to 1790. FRSL.

person_044.name: ArthurYoung
person_044.description: Agricultural writer and Secretary to the Board of Agriculture. FRSL.

person_295.name: GeorgeFinch
person_295.description: 9th Earl of Winchelsea. President of the Royal Institution, 1799-1813. FRSL.

person_105.name: ThomasPoole
person_105.description: Tanner based in Nether Stowey, philanthropist and essayist; a friend of Davy and Coleridge.

person_269.name: LuigiGalvani
person_269.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him to refer to the generation of electric current by chemical action.

person_083.name: EdmundBurke
person_083.description: Irish politician, philosopher and economist who sat as MP for various English constituencies. Originally a Whig, supporting the American rebellion and the abolition of slavery, his strong opposition to the French Revolution led him to support Pitt. He also wrote an influential book on aesthetics.

person_784.name: Daniel GabrielFahrenheit
person_784.description: German physicist, inventor, and scientific instrument maker, who invented the mercury-in-glass thermometer. The temperature scale he proposed is named after him. ForMemRSL.

person_068.name: SmithsonTennant
person_068.description: Tennant was a botanist and chemist and knew Davy through agricultural improvements. Appointed Professor of Chemistry at Cambridge University in 1813, he was killed in a riding accident in France. FRSL.

person_003.name: WilliamAllen
person_003.description: Allen was a Quaker who worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Davy asked him to give lectures on natural philosophy at the RI. FRSL.

person_135.name: JosiahWedgwood
person_135.description: Renowned British potter whose factory was at Etruria near Stoke-on-Trent. A strong supporter of the abolition of the slave trade and of slavery, he was closely connected with other industrialists in the Midlands. FRSL.

person_498.name: JohnCuthbertson
person_498.description: English-born scientific instrument maker who spent much of his career in the Netherlands. Working with Van Marum, he developed glass-plated frictional electrical machines.

person_193.name: JamesWoodhouse
person_193.description: Physician and professor of chemistry at University of Pennslyvania from 1795. Visited London in 1802 where he met Davy and later repeated his experiments on nitrous oxide.

person_346.name: JohnEgerton
person_346.description: MP for Chester and from 1814 8th baronet. Landowner who found a vein of copper ore on his land and who asked Davy for advice.

person_347.name: ShuteBarrington
person_347.description: Bishop of Durham, 1791 until death. An early Proprietor of the Royal Institution who hosted Davy when he was in the North-East working on his safety lamp.

person_288.name: ThomasBernard
person_288.description: Philantropist and a founding member of the Royal Institution serving as an early Treasurer. Later influential in running the institution, especially its lecture programme.

person_352.name: WilsonLowry
person_352.description: An engraver for scientific publications and a founder of the Geological Society of London. FRSL.

person_639.name: Johann RudolfGlauber
person_639.description: German-Dutch alchemist and chemist. He discovered sodium sulphate in 1625 which was named 'Glauber's salt'.

person_359.name: AnthonyWrangham
person_359.description: A stationer whose shop was in New Bond Street.

person_226.name: ThomasThomson
person_226.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

place_1349.name: Oxford Street
place_1349.description: Oxford Street is a major road in the City of Westminster in the West End of London, running from Tottenham Court Road to Marble Arch via Oxford Circus. It marks the notional boundary between the areas of Fitzrovia and Marylebone to the north, with Soho and Mayfair to its immediate south.

place_1348.name: Houndsditch
place_1348.description: Houndsditch is a street running through parts of the Portsoken and Bishopsgate Without wards of the City of London; areas which are also a part of the East End of London. The road follows the line of the outside edge of the ditch which once ran outside the London Wall.

place_077.name: Belfast
place_077.description: Belfast is the capital city of Northern Ireland.

place_132.name: Fairhead
place_132.description: Fairhead is a spectacular 5km long, 82m high cliff above the sea at Ballycastle, County Antrim, Northern Ireland. It is a dolerite sill.

place_122.name: Wales
place_122.description: Wales is a country in southwest Great Britain known for its rugged coastline, mountainous national parks, distinctive Welsh language and Celtic culture.

place_126.name: Giant's Causeway
place_126.description: The Giant's Causeway is an extensive area of columnar basalt in County Antrim, Northern Ireland, formed by an ancient volcanic fissure eruption.

place_146.name: Portrush
place_146.description: A small seaside town on north coast of County Antrim, Northern Ireland.

place_297.name: Herefordshire
place_297.description: A county in the West Midlands, England.

place_243.name: Carrara
place_243.description: Carrara is a city in central Italy.

place_047.name: Donegal
place_047.description: Donegal is a town at the mouth of the River Eske, in north-west Ireland.

place_524.name: Cadogan Street
place_524.description: In Kensington, London; spelt 'Cadogen' by Davy.

place_071.name: London
place_071.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

otherwork_107.name: The Bakerian Lecture, on some new Phenomena of chemical Changes produced by Electricity ...
otherwork_107.author: Humphry Davy
